												Bejeweled 3 is probably one of the best Match 3 games available on Steam, or if not, then it's definitely the most complex one. It features various game styles, thus satisfying different gamer personalities. If you like to be under pressure, then there's the Lightning Mode, in which you have a timer that you can be increased by quickly match some special time gems. Diamond mine provides a similar tension: there's a timer too, but in this mode you dig in the stone and sand by matching 3 - 5 gems in order to uncover treasures. However the most stressful game mode is probably Ice Storm - in which you have to fight the climbing columns of ice that quickly threaten to cover the entire board; to prevent this you need to have quick reflexes and a very good perception of the available matches. In order to beat this game mode, I had to switch to mouse and keyboard controls (mouseovering the tile selects it and WASD moves it in the corresponding direction).

On the contrary, for those that like a more relaxed approach, there's the Zen mode - the classic Match 3 in which you can enable/disable different relaxing background effects and positive affirmations. Another relaxed mode, but more suitable for those that have an analytical mind or love to strategically solve a puzzle, is the Butterfly mode, in which some of the gems are transformed into butterflies that automatically move one tile up whenever another match is made; having one of them reach the top of the board ends the game. This implies that you have to plan ahead your moves and optimize the matches so that they contain as many butterflies as possible.

I found Poker mode to be the least attractive of all these modes - you are required to build certain poker hands by having consecutive matches of the same colors. It's a game of chance, since your poker hands highly depend on the randomness of the current tiles.Lastly, there's the Quest mode that contains 40 variations of all these described above: finding a certain number of treasures or freeing a certain number of butterflies, or ticking bombs that need to be matched before the timer wears off etc.The game adapts itself to the game mode you're playing. For example, in Diamond Mine or Ice Storm mode the game will provide you with suitable gems to create matches or 4 or 5 which result in special gems that help clearing up the board faster. In Poker mode you‚Äôre more likely to have gems of the same color grouped together, thus facilitating the process of obtaining good poker hands.All-in-all, this is a good Match 3 game, if you enjoy the style. But it's quite addictive, so it will probably keep you entertained for hours. Even more so, going for 100% achievements requires a lot of time of grinding.More reviews on the Lilly's Corner Curator page

												Long before there was Candy Crush, there was Bejeweled. This is a simple, casual game with a grid that requires you to shift colored jewels and match them into lines of 3 - 5. You can only shift 2 jewels if it will result in a line of 3+ matching colors. Very easy game, but where this game blossoms is all of the mini games / variations of it. Dozens of modes, all centered around making lines. There is classic mode that has you going through levels making lines, lightning rush, which has a very limited time and you need to collect time ups to keep going, diamond mine, where you need to match lines near the bottom rock to destroy the rock and progress further down. Bejeweled poker which every line is like a hand gains you something similar to a card in poker. Butterfly mode has you making lines with jewel butterflies to keep them from reaching the top of the screen where it will be an end of game. There is also a never ending zen mode, which is just like classic only without levels that break the flow of what you have going. Finally, there is an ice breaker mode which forces you to keep up with rising and freezing water. Once a line gets frozen enough its game over.In a way, I prefer Candy Crush, because they have focus on levels, rather than letting you free to pick modes to play. I just feel overwhelmed with all of the choices and just end up playing 'classic' mode for the most part. On a plus side, unlike Candy Crush, there are no micro transactions. You've bought the whole game and need to unlock the modes.Bejeweled 3 has a level system that keeps track of all of your points throughout all of your games and a high score amongst your friends. That seems to be my real driving force to play the game, just to beat my friend's high scores and since every time you play, you start with a random grid of jewels, its got something to do with luck as well as skill.I can recommend the game, but I could recommend it more on the phone. I just feel there are better games I could be playing on my PC than something as simple as this. Tetris sold Gameboys, not  Nintendo Entertainment Systems.

												Bejeweled 3 is what they call a 'match 3' game, meaning you need to combine three or more of the same items on the game board, which then disappear, to score points. In this case those items are jewels that come in 7 different colors.You decide how complex you want this basic principle to become by selecting one of the 8 game modes. Some modes are very casual, like 'classic', 'poker' and 'zen'. Others are more intense because they add a timer of some sort to the game board. There is also a 'quest mode' in which you will play all of the game modes in some form, easy versions at first and more difficult with each level. You don't need to finish all of the games of one level in order to play games from the next level, so if there are one or two game modes you don't like, it's no problem to just skip those each time and progress to the next level anyway.In each mode, the game will explain clearly what the objective is and what the specific 'twists' for that game mode are. The background music is quite nice but you can switch it off through the Options menu if you want.There are a lot of Steam Achievements to be had, which adds even more challenges. Some achievements are built up to by simply playing the game, others are specific goals to be reached in one or more of the game modes.I recommend giving Bejeweled 3 a try if you're at least a bit into puzzle games, and even more so if you can get it on sale.

												It has been many years since I had my phase of Bejeweled 3 addiction, and those are fond memories indeed.I'll review Bejeweled 3 here as I remember it.Bejeweled 3 is the amazing sequel and massive improvement to Bejeweled 2 that none of us would have seen coming. Bringing with it surprising, positive innovations while still preserving the option of the great core gameplay of Bejeweled that we have always known and loved. There's not really much to be said about the gameplay other than it's Bejeweled, but better and expanded, taken in brilliant new directions while preserving the old. The presentation of it all brings the experience as a whole to such a greater level than we'd have ever imagined. The new visual splendor is exciting, pumping, and filled with eye-candy while at the same time being beautiful and serene, and most importantly, still conveys the gameplay without obstruction or serious distraction. It is accompanied by magnificent audio design, with the sound effects adding that satisfying edge to each and every move, while being clear and distinctive to give more feedback as to the state of the game and our actions within. with more skilled matches giving more and more satisfying and exciting audio responses. The soundtrack is simply phenomenal, a beautiful collection of tracks by demoscene composer Peter Hajba that both serve to immerse you in the experience of the game while also conveying the mood, ranging from blissful in the Zen soundtracks to heart-racing in the Ice and Lightning modes. Bejeweled 3 is an incredible example of taking a simple, previously lighthearted and arcadey 2D puzzle game with no story, no defined world, no characters, and all that and turning it in to a wholly immersive experience, bringing with it a sense of awe and so many different feelings of either bliss, rage, rage, or hecticness all based around the core swapping-gems gameplay.The only shortcomings that come to mind are generally in regards to aging. The visuals can feel a bit low res now on a big screen or high res display. But that's reallly the only possible criticism here.It was the real Popcap's last game before their tragic acquisition and subsequent adulteration. And what a magnificent note to go out on it was!Rest in peace Popcap Games: 2000 - 2011.Verdict: BUY IT - even at its non-sale price, it will provide massive amounts of value and fun. It makes an excellent addition to every Steam library.

												I didn't think I could ever get into puzzle games until I picked this one up.The Bejeweled franchise is similar to those typical facebook game apps (Candy Crush being a good example), where you must match identical gems next to each other by swapping them across the screen.  However, you can only swap gems that are above, below, and to the left and right of each other.  The game not only challenges your eyesight, but your strategical skills as well.The main game can keep you entertained for a couple hours, though it offers other gamemodes if it feels too repetitive.  Some require you to work under a time limit, destroying gems to accomplish objectives, and more. You'll find that a couple gamemodes may require you to plan ahead while you play on to guarantee your success.Obviously, the game is perfect for casual gamers and competitive players alike.  I am a little disappointed that the main game (Classic mode) usually predetermines your outcome for you.  You can find yourself reaching past level 10+, or even lose at the beginning of level 2 - all because of the gem randomizer.  A "NO MORE MOVES" announcement will pop up on the screen, which means...well, there are no more successful gem movements you can make.  This is the only way to get a game over, but it comes out of nowhere and you can't do anything about it.  There may be some kind of strategy to minimize your chances (AKA scoring as many points as possible in single turns to move to the next level), but you are going to lose randomly eventually.Overall it's still worth a buy with the amount of content provided.  The game has an amazing HD polish, complimented by the clear sound effects.  Go ahead and give it a try!

Classic has you going for high scores, Zen lets you relax and match gems..forever, really, Lightning makes you panic as you try to gain extra time while using the 60 seconds given to score tons of points, the amazing Quest mode that REALLY changes the way you play Bejeweled, and there are so many others.. Speaking of candies, this game has awesome earcandy as well. The music is quite enjoyable and another thing I adore about this game..I honestly can't say more. If you haven't bought this game, I HIGHLY recommend it. 												I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews - Game 23Bejeweled 3Purchase Date: 3/6/2014Match 3 puzzle games have been around a long time, and Bejeweled is one of the older series of these games.  If you ever played that awful Candy Crush Saga, then you can think of Bejeweled as it's much less obnoxious uncle.Bejeweled 3 is a match 3 game first, and not a mobile game, so thankfully it doesn't have a lot of the annoying mechanics that you find in the typical mobile game.  It's not begging you to add friends or buy gems or enticing you to click on a picture of Kate Upton's boobs to download the latest version of Fire Age.  Bejewled 3 gives you a screen full of gems, and it wants you to match 3 of them, and that's as complicated as it gets.In fairness, I should add that this version of Bejewled does come with 8 different game modes.  4 of these you get immediately, and as you progress in each game mode you will unlock an additional game mode.  So it does vary up the gameplay somewhat.  Some of the game modes are timed, while others are more strategic.  It also has a Zen mode where you can just mindlessly match gems as long as you want.So the important question you need to ask yourself is, do you like matching gems?  Because if you like matching gems, then this game is for you.  If you don't like matching gems, then you should stop reading this review and get back to playing Fire Age.

												Out of all the nostalgia that old PC games brought me since Windows 98, one that stood out for me was the Bejeweled Deluxe series. Branching from a trillogy to two extensive games such as Bejeweled Twist and Bejeweled Blitz (a more competitve version of Lightning). Which I'd also recommend playing if you own a facebook account. Bejeweled 2 & 3 are probably my most favorite to play to this day. Part of it brings me back to my younger days when I had a computer all to myself for the first time and I explored all the different games my parents installed and the ones that were set up by default when you purchased the operating system. In Bejeweled 2, you saw a massive installment in comparison to the first immediately. You could do puzzles and explore beautifully designed planets all while using your head to solve complex puzzles throughout your journey. Also it introduced us to the amazing use of the Hyper Cube and the Flame gem. The art alone still is breathtaking to look at if you played B2 today. As a fellow artist. I can appreciate the amount of skill and determination these developers put in to create these beautiful and stunning planetary landscapes. Now for Bejeweled 3, a whole new world is brought before you in a whole new environment instead of outer space. You are surrounded in ancient marble remains of lost cities and temples along side with some olden statues of mighty animals. All with beautiful animations if your computer can handle the highest settings. B3 brings back "Endless" which has been renamed to "Zen" in this version while a bunch more levels to surpass compared to B2. The rest you will have to try out for yourself to see. Lastly, one thing I admire about the Steam version of B3 is that you can compete with your high scores against your fellow Steam friends. Unlike in the original B3, you could only have a sense of competition if more than one person used your computer and liked playing B3 as much as you do. So with that said. I'd give this game a 10/10 for beautiful art, animation, & addictive gameplay!

You can also enable features like breath modulation - with or without visual indicator. Well it has inspired many clones to be created if that doesn't show potential I don't know what will. But enough over the cheap and expensive rip offs, this game is a great puzzle game, the variations in game modes can be considered completely new games that really show the beauty of the core mechanic, the way the objectives are set allow you "the player" to think in strategically different ways, from a relaxed slow paced to super tense  -OH NO- moments. Although I myself am a fan of the puzzle league series it is hard for me to adapt my oh so spoiled  keen eye which had to reconstruct the complete scene in seconds to finding combo's and such in this one move per turn game. 												Bejeweled 3 is a fun match 3 game. You might have heard of the series and genre before, so let's skip the basics and go straight to the modes:CLASSICClassic is the most basic mode in the game. Swap gems, match gems, earn points, gain levels, repeat. This process continues until you enter a stalemate (i.e. no possible moves), in which case a booming voice will remind you that you have "no more moves", and the game ends.ZENZen is the easiest mode in the game. It's the exact same as classic mode, except the gems enter the board in such a way that there is always at least one possible move for you. The mode was developed with the help of scientists to help players relax.LIGHTNINGThe most popular mode in the game, Lightning is the classic "don't let the timer stop" mode, with a twist. A gem with a number on it has a chance of appearing whenever you destroy other gems. If you manage to match that gem, it will be added to a literal 'time capsule', where once the timer reaches zero, the time in the capsule is released, the score multiplier rises, and the game continues for as long as the time that was in the capsule. Repeat this process until when the timer reaches 0 but there is no time in the capsule, in which case the game will end. It's a simple mode with a long explanation.QUESTQuest is a mode which has almost 40 minigames to challenge you to. You start with only 8 minigames unlocked, but once you complete at least 4 of them, another set of 8 minigames will be unlocked, and then once you complete 4 of those, you unlock the third set, and so on. There are 5 sets of minigames, so it isn't that repetitive. Fun fact: this is the only mode in the game with a backstory behind it, but it isn't mentioned in the game.The next modes are secret modes, so unless you've unlocked them all, avoid this section.POKERIn Poker, the board becomes the ultimate poker table as the game becomes more about chance than skill or speed. You're given a hand of 5 blank poker cards. As you make matches, these cards show decals of the gem color matched. The game becomes something out of the movie Inception as now you have to match matches, and better matches give more points. Once all 5 cards have decals on them, the colors are checked, you get your points, and the cards are discarded. 												Bejeweled 3 is a fun match 3 game. You might have heard of the series and genre before, so let's skip the basics and go straight to the modes:CLASSICClassic is the most basic mode in the game. Swap gems, match gems, earn points, gain levels, repeat. This process continues until you enter a stalemate (i.e. no possible moves), in which case a booming voice will remind you that you have "no more moves", and the game ends.ZENZen is the easiest mode in the game. It's the exact same as classic mode, except the gems enter the board in such a way that there is always at least one possible move for you. The mode was developed with the help of scientists to help players relax.LIGHTNINGThe most popular mode in the game, Lightning is the classic "don't let the timer stop" mode, with a twist. A gem with a number on it has a chance of appearing whenever you destroy other gems. If you manage to match that gem, it will be added to a literal 'time capsule', where once the timer reaches zero, the time in the capsule is released, the score multiplier rises, and the game continues for as long as the time that was in the capsule. Repeat this process until when the timer reaches 0 but there is no time in the capsule, in which case the game will end. It's a simple mode with a long explanation.QUESTQuest is a mode which has almost 40 minigames to challenge you to. You start with only 8 minigames unlocked, but once you complete at least 4 of them, another set of 8 minigames will be unlocked, and then once you complete 4 of those, you unlock the third set, and so on. There are 5 sets of minigames, so it isn't that repetitive. 												This is how you create a match 3 puzzle game.First off, the aesthetics are astounding. The graphics are incredible and the attention to detail is fantastic. Powered up gems flicker and give off light, and the stage transition looks and runs incredibly well even on my terrible Intel Integrated Graphics Card (which chokes on such intensive games such as They Bleed Pixels and Claydunn X2). The music sounds like something out of an RPG or strategy game. The game greets you every time you start it.The basic game mode is straight up match 3 at its purest. No needless microtransactions, no extra powerups to earn, no items to bring down to the bottom, no need to break every single square of the game board. What really makes ther game shine, is the other unique game modes. Poker mode makes it so every match turns into a card. Lightning mode is similar to Bejeweled Blitz. Quest mode has you playing through various unique challenges. The board does not start out with matches. You can also never run out of moves in any mode except in Classic mode. None of these modes really feel too unfair, frustrating, or tedious.The only issues I have with the game is that the Zen Mode is kind of tacked on (because all gamers need random motivational quotes to show up on screen while having on an effect that appearently causes nausea!). The other issue is that the entire game is mostly luck based. Though, that's really a problem with the genre itself.This game is absolutely worth $10. I will never play Candy Crush again.

												If you're a Bejeweled beginner, here's how it works. Different-colored jewels fill an eight-by-eight board. To wipe them away, you create groups of at least three gems by swapping one gem with one located directly beside, above, or below it. This causes those gems to disappear and the ones above to drop down, allowing for new jewels to appear at the top. Matching four or more gems together creates a special gem that will explode and remove surrounding jewels when it is matched; the more jewels matched, the more powerful the explosion. Matching like-colored gems in a T- or L-shaped pattern creates a Box gem that will zap away all gems of a particular color.

												If you're a Bejeweled beginner, here's how it works. Different-colored jewels fill an eight-by-eight board. To wipe them away, you create groups of at least three gems by swapping one gem with one located directly beside, above, or below it. This causes those gems to disappear and the ones above to drop down, allowing for new jewels to appear at the top. Matching four or more gems together creates a special gem that will explode and remove surrounding jewels when it is matched; the more jewels matched, the more powerful the explosion. Matching like-colored gems in a T- or L-shaped pattern creates a Box gem that will zap away all gems of a particular color.

												It's hard for me not to love any Bejeweled game, even before I start to play them, and Bejeweled 3 definitely didn't let me down there. I didn't think they could top 2, but they really outdid themselves here. Most of the modes/challenges will be familiar to anyone already familiar with Bejeweled game--the lightning blitz, butterflies, the mines, and even the more recent poker. 												Bejeweled is a classic puzzle game at this point - you've probably played it or at least heard of it.  If you're not sure if you'll like the gameplay try it out online.If you DO like Bejeweled, you'll like the Steam version of Bejeweled 3.  I haven't played the latest version available free online; however, this current version has a lot of really nice features that flesh out the game and make it worth having.For one, the graphical transitions have seriously been kicked up a notch.  In between levels you enter some kind of crazy wormhole thing and watch the gems fly onto the new board.  The audio is also very high quality, with a booming voice that lets you know when you've made an awesome play along with really high-quality ambient noises and music.Speaking of Ambient Noises and Music, Bejeweled 3 contains a Zen Mode (aka Endless) that includes a lot of options and settings utilized as metitation aides.  Breath modulation (breathe in / breathe out, set the speed) with a visual indicator, adjustable ambient sounds (waterfall, crickets, etc.), adjustable mantras that pop up on-screen while you play (subliminal mantras also available), and even binaural beats which are basically low level sound waves that blast into your head while you wear headphones.  There are several selectable options along with explanations on how they're supposed to make you feel / help you meditate along with a big health warning saying basically, "If you start hallucinating you should probably stop with the Binaural Beats."  I tried them for awhile and I felt like it was working, my eyes started glossing over while I played.  YMMV.  Reminded me of the random noises at the end of certain Tool songs.In addition to the above mode you've got your Classic gameplay, Poker (match gems to make the best hand), Butterfly (capture certain "gems"), Lightning, Ice Storm (earn points to keep playing), Quest (complete missions), and Diamond Mine (dig down).Once again, I recommend Bejeweled 3 if you like Bejeweled.  It's well worth grabbing this steam version.

												Addictive puzzler.When I first loaded up Bejeweled 3 I was thinking to myself "Here we go again, another puzzle game". Incredibly, such game had me hooked for 1.5 hours straight and still manages to intice me to play some some more.Gameplay is reminiscent of other puzzle games with a few twists in store. The aim of bejeweled is to match 3 of the same shapes together horizontally or vertically. You do this by swapping two shapes through clicking on one shape and then the other one. Each match removes the row of shapes, earns points and allows other shapes above to drop down. You can improve your score by doing combos (which is matching one shape, causing other shapes to match as well). Should you match a group of 4 or more shapes, the shapes will become charged up. When charged up shapes are matched with the same shapes, they explode, destroying shapes in a area around it and earing extra points.  When you are struggling to find a match, you can click on the 'Hint' button which indicates a shape you can move to form a match. There are various game modes such as a casual (no timer or set objectives), challenges (must meet objectives to pass), endless mode etc.Extra game modes can be unlocked by meeting a set score in previous game modes. With plenty of game modes to play, unlock as well as achievements to gain, there is plenty of replayability available.Music instills a feeling of serenity. Calm music is played, which is great for calming yourself when solving puzzles. Sound effects for matches and explosions are good as well. The announcer who basically shouts comments based on how well you play (number of combos), reminds me of the announcer from Mortal Combat (which is a plus).Graphics are colourful. The 2D graphics are vibrant and eye catching.As with many puzzle games there is no story, which isn't necessary anyway.If you want to play a puzzle game that will have you hooked, you will not be dissapointed with Bejeweled 3.

												Simply put: this is the game I wish all the other Bejeweled games could have been.Gem SwappingOverall, the gem-swapping engine has been tweaked (or overhauled, I don't know), and it's obvious some serious thought was put into ironing out all the minor frustrations I've had with it. You can swap any gem at almost any time except when they're actively falling down the board. This means you can swap a gem into a falling column of other gems, make swaps while board animations are happening, and in a few other surprising places. It feels very polished (no pun intended).Game ModesPretty much every mode from the first and second games are in there, plus a mode called Lightning that's very much like Bejeweled Blitz (though improved also, with no annoying Facebook tie-in), and a couple other non-timed modes that are seriously challenging and fun.The new non-timed modes include Poker, in which you create "hands" of cards by strategically matching gems. Butterflies has insect-gems that swap themselves upward on the board each time the player moves, and the game's over if the spider at the top catches any.Diamond Mine uses gem swaps to dig through dirt in search of treasure; clearing out enough dirt adds a bit of time to the countdown. Ice Storm features rising columns of ice behind the board that is shattered by swapping gems over them; if any columns freeze, the game is over.GraphicsThe graphics this time around are built for HD resolutions, and it makes a surprising difference. Going all the way up to 1080p the art lines were sharp and not distorted. Previous games were limited to specific 4:3 resolutions.The hardware-accelerated effects seem more balanced this time around. In Bejeweled 2, the lighting from the special gems would become so intense you couldn't tell what color any gem around it was anymore. This led to me disabling hardware acceleration entirely, which was a shame since it looked so good otherwise. It's on by default in Bejeweled 3, and the only time I've had difficulty is during other effects from different game modes, which is a huge improvement.It runs at a really smooth framerate on my laptop, but I'm on an Alienware 17 with a decent mobile graphics card. The game drops frames on Butterflies mode when there's a lot going on at once, but is otherwise great. On my wife's laptop (a Sony VAIO from 2010) it's a little less smooth, but still fully playable.OverallI'll be playing this game over other Bejeweled versions from now on. It's got some high replayability due to the various badges. Most have multiple levels (Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum) so they're actually fun to try for.

												Match-3 is about as basic as games get. Seriously, it's the first type of game most people are tasked with creating in game design school. So you've got to make an exceptional match-3 in order to deserve any praise for the task. The two most praised names in match-3 are Puzzle Quest, renowned for turning match-3 into a remarkably fun RPG, and Bejeweled.The original Bejeweled was far more basic than Puzzle Quest, featuring a basic match-3 until you have no more matches gametype, and a time attack mode. These persisted into Bejeweled 2, which got a little creative on us, adding in a puzzle mode, some secret extra modes to spice things up, and special gems for matching 4 or 5 gems at once. Still not as unique as Puzzle Quest, but getting there.So what sets Bejeweled 3 apart?Two things, really. Game modes, which have evolved immensely from the previous two installments, and presentation. The game plays so smoothly. Matching feels great. Explosions feel great. The sound effects and vocal work both sound great. Everything is easy to figure out and menus are not a pain to navigate. B3 is even pleasant to look at.As for the game modes, the match until you can't match anymore (Classic) and time attack (Lightning) return once again. Endless mode returns from Bejeweled 2 in the form of "Zen Mode", which is basically the same exact thing as Endless Mode (no end to the game, play as long and as poorly as you please), only with the addition of a set of gimmicky zen features (such as sound and visuals to help control your breathing, and relaxing background noise of the nature variety). Puzzle Mode is gone, and now replaced with a much cooler Quest Mode. In this mode, you are given five set of eight different missions to complete, which can range from quick snippets of one of the game's hidden modes with set goals, to special gametypes unique to this mode, involving things like uncovering artifacts in sand, balancing the number of red and blue gems matched, and turning the entire playfield gold.I mentioned hidden modes, and yes those are back. Only this time, they're much easier to unlock than in Bejeweled 2, because I guess PopCap realized that keeping people playing longer through added functionality might work better than expecting them to play nearly 300 levels of Endless Mode in order to unlock the basic time attack mode, but with altered scoring.The hidden modes of B3 are much better than B2's offerings, as well. Poker Mode is unlocked through Classic Mode, and kind of... well okay, Poker sort of sucks, really. It would be nicer with a larger board or a gem drop algorithm that's slightly more in your favor. In this mode, you try to complete poker hands by making five matches in a row. As you go, skulls will appear over the next-lowest non-skulled hand in the hand info box to the side. You can clear these skulls off by getting enough points, but if you match a hand with a skull over it, a coin flip determines whether you keep playing or game over. And this is what I'm talking about. It really seems as though they added the coin flip in in lieu of making the game a little more playable. It's fun, but sometimes you just don't get enough good gem drops to make decents hands, for several hands in a row.Butterflies Mode is much more fun, and is unlocked by playing Zen Mode for only a little while. In Butterflies, butterfly gems float up the board one space every time you make a move. If they reach the top and stay there for too long, the board freezes and you lose, but you can clear them by matching them with other gems. Ice Storm has you fighting off continuously rising pillars of ice by matching gems in their columns. Horizontal matches don't lower the pillars much, but can hit multiple at once, whereas vertical matches will only hit one pillar, but will drop it to the bottom of the screen. Special gems have varying results.Diamond Mine is my favorite mode to play. In this one, you have block of dirt on the bottom of the screen, and must clear them by making matches next to them or hitting them with special gems. Clearing all rows above a certain line drops the line down further and adds precious seconds to the timer. As you dig, you'll collect gold and ancient artifacts which will add to your score.Also, there are star gems now. Created for making a horizontal and vertical match with one gem, these take out the entire row AND column that they occupy when matched.The leaderboards are interesting, and took me a little while to figure out. I initially thought they had glitched up. Turns out, your top score is saved as your Steam display name, and all lower scores are saved under your in-game name. None of my friends have played this yet, but I'm willing to assume that only your top score is displayed on your friends' boards, but your own extra scores are there for you to personally see and improve upon.My biggest complaint is simply an issue that comes with the match-3 territory, and that's that sometimes you'll lose for just no good reason at all. This ties into my complaint with Poker Mode. The issue is that sometimes you'll desperately need a thing that just won't drop, or you need to make a match on the opposite side of the board, but the gems seem to only want to fall in a pattern which keeps you on the wrong side and oh look time's up. I would rage if I cared more.If you want match-3 with an adventure and a story, Puzzle Quest is the way to go. If you just want to match gems and maybe do it in some unique and fun ways, then Bejeweled 3 is the best way to do so that I have personally found.

												Simply put: this is the game I wish all the other Bejeweled games could have been.Gem SwappingOverall, the gem-swapping engine has been tweaked (or overhauled, I don't know), and it's obvious some serious thought was put into ironing out all the minor frustrations I've had with it. You can swap any gem at almost any time except when they're actively falling down the board. This means you can swap a gem into a falling column of other gems, make swaps while board animations are happening, and in a few other surprising places. It feels very polished (no pun intended).Game ModesPretty much every mode from the first and second games are in there, plus a mode called Lightning that's very much like Bejeweled Blitz (though improved also, with no annoying Facebook tie-in), and a couple other non-timed modes that are seriously challenging and fun.The new non-timed modes include Poker, in which you create "hands" of cards by strategically matching gems. Butterflies has insect-gems that swap themselves upward on the board each time the player moves, and the game's over if the spider at the top catches any.Diamond Mine uses gem swaps to dig through dirt in search of treasure; clearing out enough dirt adds a bit of time to the countdown. Ice Storm features rising columns of ice behind the board that is shattered by swapping gems over them; if any columns freeze, the game is over.GraphicsThe graphics this time around are built for HD resolutions, and it makes a surprising difference. Going all the way up to 1080p the art lines were sharp and not distorted. Previous games were limited to specific 4:3 resolutions.The hardware-accelerated effects seem more balanced this time around. In Bejeweled 2, the lighting from the special gems would become so intense you couldn't tell what color any gem around it was anymore. This led to me disabling hardware acceleration entirely, which was a shame since it looked so good otherwise. It's on by default in Bejeweled 3, and the only time I've had difficulty is during other effects from different game modes, which is a huge improvement.It runs at a really smooth framerate on my laptop, but I'm on an Alienware 17 with a decent mobile graphics card. The game drops frames on Butterflies mode when there's a lot going on at once, but is otherwise great. On my wife's laptop (a Sony VAIO from 2010) it's a little less smooth, but still fully playable.OverallI'll be playing this game over other Bejeweled versions from now on. It's got some high replayability due to the various badges. Most have multiple levels (Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum) so they're actually fun to try for.
